node.title: Inside horticulture's 'dark underbelly': The unseen workers propping up the farm industry
node.description: Throughout the pandemic, farmers have become increasingly reliant on temporary migrants to fill labour shortages. But there are claims some workers are being routinely exploited — paid as little as $30 a day for back-breaking labour, while living in overcrowded, unsanitary accommodation.

node.title: Research aims to develop more resilient sauvignon blanc vines
node.description: An $18.7 million programme is aiming to introduce genetic diversity of New Zealand's sauvignon blanc grapevines.

node.title: 'Essentially fobbed off' - Sexual assault victims say they struggled to get help from ACC
node.description: Two sexual assault victims say ACC discouraged them from making claims and failed to inform them about the financial help they could be entitled to - and a lawyer says it's part of a long-running…

node.title: No troops will be charged in Kabul strike that killed 10 civilians
node.description: The investigation, conducted by Lieutenant General Sami Said, the Air Force inspector general, found no violation of law, negligence, or dereliction of duty.

node.title: Coronavirus Briefing: South Africa’s Omicron lessons
node.description: And the death of the return-to-office date.

node.title: U.S. Troops Won't Be Disciplined Over Drone Strike That Killed 7 Afghan Kids, 3 Adults
node.description: Military officials said the drone strike that killed 10 civilians in Kabul was a mistake caused by errors in communication, but no soldiers will be disciplined.

node.title: Six Months After It Was Lifted, New York's Mask Mandate Kicks Back in for Indoor Spaces
node.description: The mandate will be in effect until January 15 and violators could be fined up to $1,000, but some Republicans said they would not divert funds for it.

node.title: US Open champion tests positive for COVID-19
node.description: In September, Emma Raducanu became the first qualifier to claim a Grand Slam singles title by winning the US Open.

node.title: Norway bans serving alcohol in bid to curb Omicron surge
node.description: Restaurants and bars will no longer serve alcohol in what the government says "will feel like a lockdown", as the country expects Omicron to become the dominant variant in the coming days.

node.title: Government's announcement on traffic light setting changes prompts mixed response
node.description: Around the East Coast and Bay of Plenty regions, opinions on the traffic light setting change widely vary.

node.title: Nassar abuse victims reach $380 million settlement
node.description: In addition to the payment, the organizations have also committed to safety reforms for future athletes.

node.title: Whole Foods Dumpster Diver Finds Groceries for 'Entire Community' in Clip Viewed 2M Times
node.description: "Let's start holding companies accountable and give to those in need," wrote one frustrated commenter.

node.title: 29 Percent of U.S. COVID Deaths Occurred After Vaccines Were Open to All Adults
node.description: Wyoming and West Virginia said half of their COVID-19 deaths occurred after all U.S. adults became eligible for the vaccine, while Oklahoma reported even more.

node.title: Women Take Their Fight to Go Topless on Maryland Beaches to Supreme Court
node.description: Ocean City's 2017 ordinance bars women from sunbathing topless but doesn't uphold the same restriction for men.

node.title: Why Ethan Crumbley's Parents Face Manslaughter Charges When Only One Allegedly Bought Gun
node.description: James Crumbley bought the gun Ethan allegedly used in the November 30 shooting, but his wife is also facing charges of involuntary manslaughter.

node.title: Biden Administration Urged by Democrats to Lower Medicare Premium Hike
node.description: Most Medicare enrollees will see the premium taken from their Social Security checks, possibly taking a lot of seniors' 5.8 percent cost-of-living increase.

node.title: California is reinstating an indoor mask mandate.
node.description: The indoor mask mandate will go into effect on Wednesday and will remain until at least Jan. 15.

node.title: SCOTUS Won't Halt New York's Vaccine Mandate for Health Care Workers
node.description: The court, with three justices dissenting, refused to stop the enforcement of the mandate for health care workers that does not include religious exemptions.

node.title: California Regulators Debate Incentives for Solar Power as Costs Increase for Non-Users
node.description: Major utility companies said that solar customers are able to sell their unused energy back for more than it's worth, causing other customers to pay more.

node.title: Following U.S. Trend, Employees at Startup Crime App 'Citizen' to Unionize
node.description: "[W]hat we know now is that we've grown through this process, learning how we can better work together to deliver for our users," the company said.

node.title: NSW COVID-19 cases jump to 10-week high as unvaccinated 'freedom day' looms
node.description: NSW has recorded its largest daily number of COVID-19 cases in more than 10 weeks, with 804 new infections in the 24 hours to 8:00pm yesterday.

node.title: The Chicago Bulls postpone two games as 10 players are put in Covid-19 protocols.
node.description: This marks the first postponement of an N.B.A. game this season and a reminder of the coronavirus pandemic’s continuing prevalence.

node.title: Dating Apps Have Extended Into Virtual Bedtime Companionship Due to COVID, Loneliness
node.description: A trend is taking place in Taiwan within chat apps where individuals are keeping one other company until they literally fall asleep. And they're paying for it.

node.title: USA Gymnastics Reaches $380M With Sex Abuse Victims, 90 Percent of Athletes Agree to Terms
node.description: The settlement was filed in a federal bankruptcy court in Indianapolis, Indiana on Monday.

node.title: U.S. Soccer, Women's National Team Ink Short-Term Labor Deal as Equal Pay Claim Resurfaces
node.description: The U.S. national women's team agreed to a three-month labor contract with U.S. Soccer the same day it filed a brief to restore its equal pay claim against it.

node.title: Redditor Shares Texts From Boss Demanding They Cover Shift Last Minute, Causes Stir Online
node.description: "Do. Not. Answer. Your. Phone. When. Not. Working," one person commented on the post that has been voted on over 17,000 times.

node.title: UPS Will Pay Employees $1M After Judge Finds They Illegally Diverted Salaries to Charities
node.description: A union president encouraged UPS employees to accept the settlement and "make the company pay for what they did wrong."

node.title: Midwest Saw Record-Breaking Twisters and Deadliest December Day in Tornado History
node.description: At least 64 people have died from the storms in Kentucky alone, and officials believe the total death toll could exceed 100.

node.title: South Africa's President tests positive for COVID-19
node.description: After testing positive for COVID-19 and a surge in Omicron cases, South Africa's president urges people in South Africa to get vaccinated.

node.title: Victoria records 1,189 new COVID-19 cases and six deaths
node.description: There are now 11,051 active cases of the virus in Victoria, and 605 people have died during the current outbreak.
